Let‚Äôs honor those individuals that we lost while we fight against the fatigue we might feel. We can still save thousands of lives if we work together. Be safe, everyone.
This week when you reflect on the tragic milestone of 400k deaths, don‚Äôt think of the number; think of a person or a family you know who was affected by the virus.

Our job as regular Americans is not to save hundreds of thousands of lives but to protect ourselves and those around us. Through collective action we can conjure what is necessary to make monumental change.

The monumental number makes it harder for us to think individuals play a role in solving the problem. I used to feel like the only way to solve a massive problem is through an equally massive solution. But this minimizes the role we have in wearing a mask and social distancing.

Yes we want to honor those that we lost and recognize the scope of the suffering. But from my experience, these staggering numbers often pull us further away from the humanity of the crisis and can make us more numb to the loss. We cannot visualize how large of a number 400k is.

In the next 24 hours we will hit 400k COVID deaths. Two days later we will surpass the total deaths of Americans during WW2. I previously worked to stop genocide/mass atrocity and my advice to you is to not get fixated on the numbers but instead focus on something personal.
